case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. the two assessees

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 259 and 260 of 1958 are appeals by special leave from the judgment and orders dated August 5, 1955 of the former Travancore Cochin High Court in Income-tax Reference Appeals Nos. 6 of 1953 and 21 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and orders dated August 5, 1955, of the former Travancore Cochin High Court in Income-tax Reference Appeals Nos. 6 of 1953 and 21 of 1954.

facts.text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered on February 23, 1959 by KAPUR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. February 23. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-These two appeals by special leave raise a companymon question

facts.text: The appellant in both appeals is the Commissioner of Income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant before us in both the appeals is the Commissioner of Income-tax and the respondents are the two assessees,

facts.text: The respondents are two assessees: in one case a Bank and the other a private limited company.

anchor.surface_text: the respondents are the two assessees, in one case a Bank and the other a private limited companypany.

facts.text: In C.A. No. 259/58 the assessee is a public limited company incorporated in the State of Cochin with branches in that State as well as in British India and Travancore State.

anchor.surface_text: In C. A. No. 259/58 the assessee is a public limited companypany incorporated in the State of Cochin with branches in that State as well as in what was British India and in Travancore State.

facts.text: The assessee in C.A. No. 259/58 filed its income-tax return showing an income of Rs. 11,872 for the assessment year 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: It filed its incometax return showing an income of Rs. 11,872 for the assessment year 1948-49, its accounting year being the previous calendar year.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer determined the assessee's assessable income to be Rs. 90,947 representing only the profit made in Travancore State for 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer determined its assessable income to be Rs. 90,947 representing only the profit it made in Travancore State

facts.text: Under s. 32(1) proviso 1 of the Travancore Act, ITO refused deduction of Rs. 79,275 loss from branches outside Travancore.

anchor.surface_text: and under s. 32 1  proviso  1  of the Travancore Act he refused a deduction of Rs. 79,275 shown as loss from branches situate outside the State of Travancore,

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal held that the assessee's banking business is one and indivisible and entitled to deduct losses outside Travancore from profits in Travancore.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal held that the banking business of the assessee being one and indivisible for the purpose of determining the amount assessable to income-tax it was entitled to deduct the losses incurred outside Travancore State from the profits accruing and arising in that State.

facts.text: High Court of Travancore-Cochin answered the referred question in favour of the assessee in C.A. No. 259/58.

anchor.surface_text: This question was slightly modified by the High Court which after referring to several decided cases answered the question in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: In C.A. No. 260/58 the assessee is a private limited company with registered office in former Cochin State, carrying business in Cochin and Travancore.

anchor.surface_text: In C. A. 260/58 the assessee is a private limited companypany with its registered office in the former Cochin State. It was carrying on business at its head office in Cochin State and it also carried on business in -Travancore State.

facts.text: Assessment in C.A. 260/58 relates to previous year ending June 30, 1949, assessment year 1950-51 under Travancore Act.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment was made under the Travancore Act and relates to the previous year ending June 30, 1949, the assessment year being 1950-51.

facts.text: Assessee in C.A. 260/58 made profit of Rs. 38,998 in Travancore State and loss of Rs. 27,709 in Cochin State, seeking net profit of Rs. 2,643.

anchor.surface_text: The assesse made a profit in Travancore State and incurred a loss in the State of Cochin and sought to deduct this loss from the profit of Travancore State thus showing a net profit of Rs. 2,643.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer did not allow set-off of Cochin loss against Travancore profit in C.A. 260/58.

anchor.surface_text: This was number allowed by the Income-tax Officer and on appeal this order was companyfirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal upheld the assessment order disallowing set-off in C.A. 260/58.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal also did number accept the submissions of the assessee and upheld the order of assessment.

facts.text: High Court answered the referred question in favour of the assessee in C.A. No. 260/58.

anchor.surface_text: and was answered in favour of the assessee. The Commissioner has companye up in appeal pursuant to special leave against both these judgments.

facts.text: The scheme of the Indian Income-tax Act of 1922 is admitted by the parties to be the same as that of the Travancore Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: In order to determine the true meaning of the words of the proviso it is necessary and companyvenient to refer to the scheme of the Indian Act which is admitted by the parties to be same as that of the Travancore Act.

facts.text: Relevant sections of Travancore Act are identically worded with Indian Income-tax Act of 1922.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated that the relevant sections of the Travancore Act which govern the two appeals are identically worded with those of the Indian Incometax Act of 1922  to be called the Indian Act .

facts.text: In Appeal No. 260/58 a question arose whether the year ending June 30, 1949 was the previous year for assessment year 1950-51 but not answered by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In Appeal No. 260/ 58 a further question arose whether in the case of that assessee the year ending June 30, 1949, was the previous year for the assessment year 1950-51 with the result that it should be assessed under the Indian Income- tax Act of 1922. But this question was number answered by the High Court

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that the question common to both appeals was rightly answered by High Court in favour of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the question referred to the High Court which is companymon to the two appeals was rightly answered in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: Supreme Court does not decide the second question in C.A. No. 260/58.

anchor.surface_text: As to the second question in Civil Appeal No. 260 of 1958 we do number propose to say anything. It will be open to the assessee in that appeal to take such steps in regard to that question as it may be advised.

issues.text: whether business losses incurred in the erstwhile State of Cochin could, under the Income-tax Act of Travancore, be set off against the business profits made in the erstwhile State of Travancore

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals by special leave raise a common question of law, and that is, whether business losses incurred in the erstwhile State of Cochin could, under the Income-tax Act of Travancore, be set off against the business profits made in the erstwhile State of Travancore. In Appeal No. 260/ 58 a further question arose

anchor.surface_text: In Appeal No. 260/ 58 a further question arose whether in the case of that assessee the year ending June 30, 1949, was the previous year for the assessment year 1950-51 with the result that it should be assessed under the Indian Income- tax Act of 1922. But this question was not answered by the High Court

issues.text: Is the aforesaid sum of Rs. 79,275 a loss of the assessee arising outside the Travancore State for purpose of the first proviso to section 32(1) of the Travancore Income-tax Act ?

anchor.surface_text: the following question was referred to the High Court of Travancore-Cochin- Is the aforesaid sum of Rs. 79,275 a loss of the assessee arising outside the Travancore State for purpose of the first proviso to section 32 1  of the Travancore Income-tax Act ? This question was slightly modified by the High Court

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the loss of Rs. 27,709 arising in Cochin State could be set off against the profit of Rs. 38,998 arising in Travancore State ?

anchor.surface_text: On an application of the assessee the following question was referred to the High Court of Travancore-Cochin- Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the loss of Rs. 27,709 arising in Cochin State could be set off against the profit of Rs. 38,998 arising in Travancore State ? and was answered in favour of the assessee.

issues.text: as to how this proviso is to be construed

anchor.surface_text: So the only difference between the two sections is that in the proviso to s. 24 1  of the Indian Act instead of the words an Indian State the words British India or in an Indian State have to be substituted. The question for decision is as to how this proviso is to be construed.

arguments.claim: The proviso to s.32(1) falls in the second category of provisos which contain matter that is a fresh enactment adding to and not merely qualifying the preceding section, thus taking cases out of s.32(1) and disallowing deduction of losses from British India and other States against profits in Travancore State

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the Revenue that this proviso falls in the second category and takes the present cases out of s. 32 1  of the Travancore Act and imposes a liability to tax on the profits or gains arising in that State, disallowing a deduction of the losses in British India and in States other than Travancore State against profits made in Travancore State Rhondda Urban Council v. Taff Vale Railway  1  and Harrison v. Ward  2 .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ntroduced in 1922 before which under the Indian Act of 1918 a loss under one head of income companyld number be set off against income under another h

arguments.court_reasoning: Proviso qualifies main enactment and cannot enlarge scope or modify computation under s.10 unless language compels; distinguished Rhondda as not applicable

arguments.claim: The first proviso to s.24(1) not only affects generality of main enactment but introduces addendum modifying method of computation under s.10 by disallowing losses under business head from other territories against profits in British India/Travancore

anchor.surface_text: But it was contended on behalf of the Revenue that the first proviso to s. 24 1  of the Indian Act number only affected the generality of the main enactment but also introduced an addendum that where the profits of the business arose in what was British India in the case of the Indian Act or what was Travancore State in the case of the Travancore Act and the losses under the head business were sustained in an Indian State or in the latter case in any other Indian State or British India, these losses companyld number by virtue of the proviso be deducted from profits made in British India or Travancore State as the case may be.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: xcept and deal with a case which would otherwise fall within the general language of the main enactment, and its effect is companyfined to that case.

arguments.court_reasoning: Averse to such construction unless language compels; proviso operates only in field of main section s.24(1) for inter-head set-offs

arguments.claim: The words 'where the loss sustained is a loss of profits or gains' in the proviso necessarily apply to and restrict set-off to the business head

anchor.surface_text: It was then submitted that in the proviso the words used were where the loss sustained is a loss of profits or gains and therefore it necessarily applied to the head business in the two respective territories.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: strict the set off of profits and losses arising in Indian States only to business or to modify the mode of companyputation under s. 10 of the Indian

arguments.court_reasoning: Same words used in main s.24(1); does not justify restricting to business or modifying s.10; contrast with explicit language in s.24(2) proviso

arguments.claim: s.10 must be read with s.14(2)(c); since profits from Indian States exempt, losses from there cannot be deducted; business in s.10 means only business in British India

Commissioner of Income-tax  5 . There it was held that s. 10 of the Indian Act had to be read with s. 14 2   e  and if profits companyld number be added for the purposes of total income losses sustained also companyld number be deducted.

arguments.court_reasoning: Ignores definitions of total income/world income, ss.3,4 including foreign income for residents; s.10 does not distinguish business territories

arguments.claim: s.24(1)/32(1) proviso bars set-off only where loss in Indian States under one head sought to be set off against profits in British India under any other head; does not apply to profits/losses under business head s.10/13

anchor.surface_text: S. 24 1 , first proviso, of the Indian Income- tax Act, 1922 Is. 32 1 , first proviso, of the Travancore Act bars the right of set off only where a loss in the Indian States under one head is sought to be set off against profits in British India under any other head, and does number apply to profits and losses and companyputation thereof which fall under s. 10 of the Indian Act, companyresponding to s. 13 of the Travancore Act.

arguments.claim: Proper function of proviso is to carve out exception from main enactment; cannot enlarge scope, add new matter, or modify other sections like s.10

anchor.surface_text: Ordinarily the effect of an excepting or a qualifying proviso is to carve something out of the preceding enactment or to qualify something enacted therein which but for the proviso would be in it and such a proviso cannot be companystrued as enlarging the scope of an enactment when it can be fairly and properly companystrued without attributing to it that effect.

arguments.claim: s.24(1) only for set-off between different heads; same head like business adjusted directly under s.10, not via s.24(1)

anchor.surface_text: the Privy Council in Arunachalam Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1  held that this section was meant for a set off of profits arising under different heads and number where profits and losses had to be adjusted if they arose under the same head.

arguments.claim: Proviso must be construed harmoniously with main enactment; embraces only field covered by main provision

Assistant Commissioner of Sales Tax  2  said It is a cardinal rule of interpretation that a proviso to a particular provision of a statute only embraces the field which is companyered by the main provision.

arguments.claim: Word 'business' in s.10 not confined to British India; includes business anywhere per ss.3,4 definitions of total income

anchor.surface_text: The word business,, in s. 10 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, is number companyfined to business in British India, in view of the definition of total income and total world income and chargeability of total income under s. 3, Or the provisions Of s. 4 where in the case of a resident total income includes income, profits and gains accruing within or without British India.

arguments.claim: High Court rightly answered the common question in favour of assessee

anchor.surface_text: In our view the question referred to the High Court which is companymon to the two appeals was rightly answered in favour of the assessee.

holdings.text: S. 24(1), first proviso, of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 [i.e.] s. 32(1), first proviso, of the Travancore Act bars the right of set off only where a loss in the Indian States under one head is sought to be set off against profits in British India under any other head, and does not apply to profits and losses and computation thereof which fall under s. 10 of the Indian Act, corresponding to s. 13 of the Travancore Act.

anchor.surface_text: S. 24 1 , first proviso, of the Indian Income- tax Act, 1922 Is. 32 1 , first proviso, of the Travancore Act bars the right of set off only where a loss in the Indian States under one head is sought to be set off against profits in British India under any other head, and does

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso qualifies main s.24(1)/32(1) for inter-head set-offs only; business profits/losses adjusted under s.10/13 itself; harmonious construction with Act scheme and precedents on proviso function.

holdings.text: The word business in s. 10 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, is not confined to business in British India, in view of the definition of total income and total world income and chargeability of total income under s. 3, or the provisions of s. 4 where in the case of a resident total income includes income, profits and gains accruing within or without British India.

anchor.surface_text: chargeability of total income under s. 3, Or the provisions Of s. 4 where in the case of a resident total income includes income, profits and gains accruing within or without British India. CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 259 and 260 of 1958.

holdings.reasoning_summary: ss.3,4 define total income to include world income for residents; s.10 computation not territorially limited; rejects revenue's narrow reading.

holdings.text: s.24(1) is meant for set off of losses under one head against profits under a different head; where profits and losses arise under same head like business, they are adjusted under that head (s.10), not under s.24(1).

anchor.surface_text: the Privy Council in Arunachalam Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1  held that this section was meant for a set off of profits arising under different heads and not where profits and losses had to be adjusted if they arose under the same head.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Privy Council in Arunachalam Chettiar and this Court's Anglo-French Textiles; distinguishes intra-head from inter-head adjustments.

holdings.text: A proviso cannot be construed as enlarging the scope of the enactment, adding fresh matter, or modifying computation under other sections like s.10 unless language compels; it carves exception from main provision only.

anchor.surface_text: Ordinarily the effect of an excepting or a qualifying proviso is to carve something out of the preceding enactment or to qualify something enacted therein which but for the proviso would be in it and such a proviso cannot be construed as enlarging the scope of an enactment when it can be fairly and properly construed without attributing to it that effect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies principles from Toronto, Rhondda (distinguished), Abdul Jabar Butt, Ram Narain Sons, Madras Southern Mahratta; proviso limited to s.24(1) field.

holdings.text: The question referred to the High Court which is common to the two appeals was rightly answered in favour of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the question referred to the High Court which is common to the two appeals was rightly answered in favour of the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms High Court based on proviso not barring intra-business head set-offs across territories.

holdings.text: As to the second question in Civil Appeal No. 260 of 1958 we do not propose to say anything. It will be open to the assessee in that appeal to take such steps in regard to that question as it may be advised.
